skill.name: querying-logseq-data
skill.description: Expert in building Datalog queries for Logseq DB graphs. Auto-invokes when users need help writing Logseq queries, understanding Datalog syntax, optimizing query performance, or working with the Datascript query engine. Covers advanced query patterns, pull syntax, aggregations, and DB-specific query techniques.
skill.summary: Expert in building Datalog queries for Logseq DB graphs. Auto-invokes when users need help writing L...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based knowledge skill with no executable code. It provides Datalog query guidance for Logseq databases using only standard read-only tools (Read, Grep, Glob, WebFetch, WebSearch). No file writes, network data exfiltration, or command execution capabilities.

content.user_title: Build Logseq Datalog queries for database graphs
content.value_statement: Users struggle to write effective Datalog queries for their Logseq knowledge graphs. This skill provides expert guidance on query syntax, patterns, optimization, and the Datascript schema so users can retrieve exactly the data they need.
actual_capabilities: Build Datalog queries with :find, :where, and :in clauses
Use pull syntax to retrieve entity data with specific attributes
Create aggregation queries for count, sum, average, min, max
Define reusable query rules for complex logic
Optimize query performance with best practices
Convert simple query syntax to full Datalog queries
limitations: Does not execute queries directly in Logseq
Cannot access your actual Logseq database
Limited to query syntax guidance, not actual data retrieval
Does not modify or write to Logseq graphs

use_cases.title: Find tagged content
use_cases.description: Query all blocks or pages with specific tags like Book, Task, or Project.

use_cases.title: Track deadlines
use_cases.description: Find tasks due within date ranges or overdue items for project tracking.

use_cases.title: Build complex queries
use_cases.description: Create reusable rules, recursive queries, and aggregations for advanced data analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Basic query help
prompt_templates.scenario: Need to build a simple query
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to write a Datalog query to find all pages tagged with [Tag Name] in my Logseq graph.

prompt_templates.title: Property filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a query that finds all blocks with [Property] equal to [Value].

prompt_templates.title: Task tracking
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a query to find all tasks with status [Status] and priority [Priority] in Logseq.

prompt_templates.title: Aggregation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to use aggregation in Datalog to count items by [Field] in my Logseq database.

output_examples.input: Show me how to find all books with a rating of 5 stars
output: Here's a Datalog query to find 5-star rated books:
â€¢ Use pull syntax to retrieve full block data
â€¢ Filter by tag (Book) and property value (rating 5)
â€¢ The query finds all blocks tagged as Book where user.property/rating equals 5

best_practices: Put most selective clauses first to narrow results early in your query
Use indexed attributes like :db/ident and :block/uuid for faster lookups
Avoid wildcards in pull syntax - specify only the attributes you need
anti_patterns: Using wildcards in pull when you only need specific attributes
Not using rules for complex logic that repeats across queries
Ignoring query performance by putting broad filters before narrow ones

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Logseq mobile apps?
faq.answer: Queries work the same across desktop and mobile since they use the same Datalog engine.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of results a query can return?
faq.answer: Logseq does not hard-code limits but very large result sets may impact performance.

faq.question: Can I use these queries in Logsum plugins?
faq.answer: Yes, the plugin API exposes datascriptQuery for executing queries in plugins.

faq.question: Does this skill access my Logseq data?
faq.answer: No, this skill only provides query syntax guidance, it does not read your database.

faq.question: Why is my query running slowly?
faq.answer: Slow queries often need better clause ordering, indexed attributes, or result limits.

faq.question: How does this differ from Logsum simple query blocks?
faq.answer: Simple queries are limited; full Datalog offers aggregations, rules, and complex logic.
